title: Badgers (animation)
text:
Badgers, also known informally as Badger Badger Badger or The Badger Song, is a <a href="Flash%20animation">Flash animated</a> <a href="meme">meme</a> by British animator <a href="Jonti%20Picking">Jonti Picking</a>. It consists of 12 <a href="animated%20cartoon">animated cartoon</a> <a href="European%20badger">badgers</a> doing <a href="calisthenics">calisthenics</a>, a <a href="Amanita%20muscaria">mushroom</a> in front of a tree, and a <a href="snake">snake</a> in the <a href="desert">desert</a>. The Flash <a href="cartoon">cartoon</a> is accompanied by a bass line, above which a <a href="voiceover">voiceover</a> sings the <a href="name">name</a>s of what's shown on <a href="Electronic%20visual%20display">screen</a>.
This Flash cartoon was published on 1 September 2003. The cartoon <a href="Endless%20loop">loops</a> indefinitely.
Critical reception.
The cartoon brought Picking to the attention of <a href="MTV%20Europe">MTV Europe</a>, for whom Picking produced "<a href="Weebl%20and%20Bob">Weebl and Bob</a>". That cartoon series, together with the dancing badgers, helped Picking's website <a href="Weebl%27s%20Stuff">Weebl's Stuff</a> win a People's Choice award from users of <a href="Yahoo%21">Yahoo!</a> in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a>. "Badger Badger Badger" was also listed as one of the top five internet fads of all time by <a href="PC%20World%20%28magazine%29">PC World</a> in 2009.
Follow-up versions.
There have been several follow ups to the "Badger Badger Badger" cartoon posted to the Weebl's Stuff website. "Badgers 2" was created in 2003, and features <a href="zombie">zombie</a> badgers on a black background with a scratching sound added to the music. A Christmas-themed version, with the badgers dressed in Santa Claus suits, the mushroom replaced with a present, and the snake replaced with baby Jesus in a nativity scene, is also available, and was made in 2005. "Badgers On a Plane" consists of a scene from a "<a href="Snakes%20On%20a%20Plane">Snakes On a Plane</a>" trailer that includes badgers and a mushroom, which have been digitally edited into the scene, tumbling from their seats while a bit of the song plays in the background. In 2007, "Big Ass Badgers" was released to spoof the "<a href="Transformers%20%28film%29">Transformers</a>" film. Also in 2007, a live action version of the cartoon called "Baby Badgers" was released to promote the new Badger toys.
A "Euro 2004 Edition" was also created during the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202004">UEFA Euro 2004</a> football championship, where the badgers wore <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> football jerseys to "<a href="Association%20football">footy</a>, footy, footy" and "England! England! Goal! A goal! Oh, it's a goal, scored by England, England..." A new version titled "Footy 2010" was created for the <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2010 FIFA World Cup</a> with <a href="vuvuzela">vuvuzela</a>s drowning out the audio. Another version, titled "Realistic Football Badgers", was created in response to England's loss in the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2014 FIFA World Cup</a>.
The song is referenced in the January 2004 comic strips of JD Fraser's <a href="User%20Friendly">User Friendly</a>. A few of the characters interpreted "the song goes on about badgers, mushrooms and a snake" and that the song does not make sense.
A parody by a group called Fifth District, titled "Potter Potter Potter," depicts several images of <a href="Harry%20Potter">Harry Potter</a> dancing on the <a href="Hogwarts">Hogwarts</a> Campus, one image of <a href="Ron%20Weasley">Ron Weasley</a> dancing in another area of the campus, and <a href="Severus%20Snape">Severus Snape</a> advancing menacingly toward the figures of the bespectacled wizarding teen, with a <a href="Whomping%20Willow">Whomping Willow</a> tree and flying <a href="hippogriff">hippogriff</a>s in the background. The chant is "Potter Potter Potter Potter" and "Weasley! Weasley!" and "Snape! Snape! Oh, it's a Snape!".
In 2011, a <a href="dubstep">dubstep</a> version called "Guess I got My Badger Back" was released based on "Swagga" by <a href="Excision%20%28musician%29">Excision</a> & <a href="Datsik%20%28musician%29">Datsik</a>. On April 6, 2011, he uploaded a 3D version.
A new version of the song was launched on the <a href="Moshi%20Monsters">Moshi Monsters</a> website, where the Monsters appear on the screen as, "Moshi Moshi" is sung instead. Every now and then, there is a break where "Monster", or even rarer, "Moshling", is said instead.
On March 6, 2013, Canadian musician <a href="Devin%20Townsend">Devin Townsend</a> released a previously unreleased cover of the song while recording the album "<a href="Deconstruction%20%28Devin%20Townsend%20Project%20album%29">Deconstruction</a>".
Another adaptation of the song, "<a href="Save%20the%20Badger%20Badger%20Badger">Save the Badger Badger Badger</a>", was released on 19 May 2013, in response to proposed <a href="badger%20culling%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">badger culling in the United Kingdom</a>. The song features vocals and guitar from <a href="Brian%20May">Brian May</a> and visuals reminiscent to the 1980 film "<a href="Flash%20Gordon%20%28film%29">Flash Gordon</a>", in addition to vocals from <a href="Jonti%20Picking">Weebl</a> and <a href="Brian%20Blessed">Brian Blessed</a>. Some of the song's lyrics are changed.
